metadata.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty v. Mohamedbhai Eusufalli

facts.text: Eusufalli Ebrahimji settled immovable properties and leasehold lands upon trust by indenture dated 15-7-1938.
Trustees appointed: Eusufalli (settlor), Bai Safiabai (deceased), and their eldest son Mohamedbhai (accountable person).
Under trust deed: Settlor entitled to net income during his lifetime.

After settlor's death: Income divided into three equal shares - 1/3rd to Bai Safiabai during her lifetime; out of remaining 2/3rd, 1/3rd to Mohamedbhai and 1/3rd to maintenance of two wives and children of settlor's youngest son Salebhai (who died before trust deed).

After death of Safiabai: Trustees to divide trust properties - one equal share (half) to eldest son Mohamedbhai (or his children and wife if predeceased), according to dictates of religion; other half share to wife and children of Salebhai (two anna share to each of two wives, remaining twelve annas to children according to religion); trust to come to an end.
Assistant Controller determined value of her estate at Rs. 4,15,000/-, consisting of her individual properties and 1/3rd of trust properties.
Accountable person objected to inclusion of 1/3rd share in trust properties.
Accountable person appealed to Appellate Controller, later sought to withdraw appeal; withdrawal refused.

Appellate Controller issued notice to show cause why entire trust estate should not be included; rejected contention that trust property did not belong to deceased; included entire trust property, enhancing valuation by Rs. 5,73,000/-.
Accountable person appealed to Appellate Tribunal.
Tribunal set aside Appellate Controller's order, restored Assistant Controller's; held only 1/3rd of trust estate passed on death of deceased.
Tribunal referred three questions under s.64(1) of Estate Duty Act partly at instance of Department and partly accountable person; accountable person withdrew third question.
Gujarat High Court answered first question in favour of accountable person; did not answer second as unnecessary.
High Court judgment and order dated October 3 and 4, 1968 in Estate Duty Tax Reference No. 1 of 1968.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the whole of the Trust estate was to be included in the assessment or only a portion thereof and if so what portion.

petitioner_arguments.text: Title to trust properties vested in trustees till death of deceased; title passed to beneficiaries immediately on her death; title that passed was entire trust property; hence entire value to be included.

respondent_arguments.text: Deceased had only 1/3rd interest in trust property; that alone passed on her death; her position as trustee ending on death cannot be considered property passing.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.5(1), estate duty levied on property passing on death; s.2(15) defines property as including any interest; s.2(16) inclusive definition of passing on death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Property passing on death means change in beneficial interests before and after death; not mere change in title.

court_reasoning.text: Beneficial interest in 2/3rd income vested in others since settlor's death; deceased entitled only to 1/3rd income; only 1/3rd interest passed; change from beneficial income to legal ownership does not enlarge extent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trustee title is personal right with no monetary value, imposes duties, not property.

court_reasoning.text: Cites English authorities: beneficial enjoyment unaffected by death does not pass; no duty on mere change of title where same persons entitled before/after.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relevant is change in beneficial interest, not title.

holdings.text: Only 1/3rd interest in trust property passed on death of deceased; entire trust estate does not pass.

precedents_cited.case_name: Scott and Coutts and Co. v. Inland Revenue Commissioner
precedents_cited.relevance: Property passes if beneficial interests change before/after death.
Estate duty only on property where beneficial interest changes on death; not on prior vested interests.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahendra Rambhai Patel v. Controller of Estate Duty, Gujarat
precedents_cited.relevance: Property passing determined by change in beneficial interest on death.

statutes_cited.name: Estate Duty Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Levies duty on property passing on death; defines property and passing; only beneficial interest passes.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court and Tribunal (Assistant Controller) view that only 1/3rd of trust estate passed on death of Bai Safiabai; rejected Department's contention for entire estate.
outcome.relief_granted: None specified beyond upholding lower decisions.

key_quotes.text: "The word passes means changes hands. To ascertain whether property has passed, a comparison must be made between the persons beneficially interested the moment before the death and the persons so interested the moment after the death."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines test for property passing on death.

key_quotes.text: "In substance, only 1/3rd interest in the trust property passed on her death."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on extent of property passing.

key_quotes.text: "Her title to the property as a trustee was purely a personal right. It had no value in terms of money. It conferred no right on her. It only imposed some duties. Such a right cannot be considered as property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes trustee title from beneficial interest.
